section.title: Thinking About The Structure Of a 3D Box
section.para: In OpenGL, there are no geometries. We would build every geometry manually by describing its' vertices.

We have learnt from the previous chapters how to render a rectangle by using glDrawArrays by passing GL_TRIANGLE_STRIP as its first argument. So once we decide the 4 vertices of each face, we could assemble a 3D box in screen.
A box has 6 faces, each face has 4 vertices. So there are 24 vertices altogether. Should we describe all these 24 vertices?
Look at the figure once more. You would found that each vertices is shared by 3 edges of 3 different faces. So, we need only 8 vertices to describe a box.

Given only 8 vertices, we need to render the box using another function glDrawElements. Using glDrawElements, we do NOT fetch each vertex from the buffer straightly, rather, we can pick up the vertices we need to construct different faces.
